div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Railways Express Service for Vienna, Paris, and London.
*Special express Itinerary arriving Piraeus Friday evenings and Constantinople Saturday afternoons omitting Smyrna and Mitylene outwards.

The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrount in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakehlieh and Kossier leave Suez alternatly on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai Yambo and Jeddah; continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakin, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN.
For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez or to THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE AND HIS CRITICS
div.p: A Cairo correspondent of the “Telegraph”, in a message dated the 30th. ult., a summary of which was cabled by our London correspon­dent on the 11th. inst., writes :—
As you will have gathered from my cables, practically the sole theme of discussion in the Egyptian local Press, and the factor around

which have raged (to put it even mildly), expressions of opinions, conjectures, assertions, accusations, and dementis, has been the article in “The Daily Telegraph" by M Edward Dicey, detailing his interview with his High­ness the Khedive.

Naturally enough his Highness’s remarks as to the military occupation of Egypt, to the effect that Egypt was too wealthy, and at the same time too weak a country not to fall under the protection of some great European Power, proved the biggest bone of contention ; journalistic amenities have been indulged in as they never were before in my experience of the country, and the howls of derision on the part of the majority of the European journals have been met by aspersions on both the Khedive and Mr. Dicey by the Nationalists.

The Khedive, although in residence in Alexandria, has not felt himself constrained to modify or contradict any of Mr. Dicey’s statements, and, therefore, despite the conjec­tures of the Nationalist Press, one is bound to accept the interview published as being a substantially veracious and certainly admirably clear version of his Highness’s ideas.

There can be no logical reason for doubling that the command of the Khedive to see Mr. Dicey before the latter left for home was prompted by the desire to remove by means of publicity in an authoritative British journal, impressions conveyed by the many false and seemingly malicious reports in certain of your contemporaries. I advisedly make this state­ment, although I had not the pleasure of conferring with Mr Dicey in the short interval between his return from the palace and hi- almost immediate departure for London.

Specific charges had been made against the Khedive by a number of London newspapers. His Highness had been accused in no ambi­guous terms of bribery and corruption, and there were other insinuations which he was unable to nail to the counter in his exalted position as sovereign of a realm by the ordi­nary process of law. What more 'reasonable, then, in this peculiar position, that he should take the one course open to him, i.e., .to declare positively and publicly by means of" the pen of a leading journalist of the day that these obvious slanders and gross inuendoes had no raison d’etre.

I suggest he did not protest too much. In my humble judgment the Khedive has distinct right to repudiate by the best means at hand the suggestions which ‘.during the past few months have distressed and annoyed him, as they would any honest man He stood in the extraordinary position that he could not afford, even against his most ardent desire, to ignore any longer distinct attacks made upon his integrity, and insinuations which, despite his indignant protest, remained uncontradict­ed. His slightest move has been construed into sedition, and his lightest word interpreted as an expression of a virnlent pan-Islamite— whatever the latter phrase may mean.
And what monumental nonsense all this is, and, moreover, what a travesty of the British idea of fair play and justice

From a comparatively long experience of Egypt, and having the honour of knowing his Highness the Khedive personally, I am con­vinced that he is only too anxious to work in cordial co-operation with anyone for the well- being of his country. At the commencement of his reign (if such it may be termed) he Hung himself into an exalted position with possibly more ardour than discretion. He criticised where probably criticism was not merited and certainly not desired, and succeeded within a few months in establishing the reputation of a stormy petrel in the country. But he is no longer in his teens. His Highness to-day is a keen, discerning man of thirty-five, full of intelligent energy, and willing and capable to work for the good of his. subjects, whose wants and aspirations he appreciates surely much better than the casual observers who make it their weekly duty to belittle him in the home Press.

In face of the many statements to which I have referred, I am convinced the majority of your readers will agree that he was justified in giving an emphatic and conclusive denial to these libellous creations of imaginative minds ; this I imagine he succeeded in doing in the interview he accorded Mr. Dicey.

Naturally, the Khedive’s declarations have caused a great storm in the Nationalist camp. The Nationalists’ organs alternate in ex­pressing unbelief in Mr. Dicey’s interpretation of his Highness’s statements and the declaration that the Nationalist cause is one thing and the Khedive’s personal idea quite another. So far as that goes, Mustapha Pasha Kamel has been consistently honest in declaring that the Khedive has no lot or part in the present Nationalist movement. I believe him. It is not my pleasure to have the personal acquaint­ance of Mustapha Pasha Kamel or any of the gentlemen working on his various newspapers, but it has always struck me that they are conducting a campaign in a legitimate manner : that they purposely and very carefully avoid appealing to the religious sentiment of the country, and that finally they are in no way responsible for whatever unrest there may be in the country.
In regard to the talk of unrest, I might give it an unqualified denial.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: New Nile Gauge.
A Nile gauge has been built at Merowe during May by the irrigation Department.
Mineral Waters.
We' remind our readers that Spathis' cele minerals are the best in Egypt. [Advt ]
Savoy Palace Hotel
The Administration of the Savoy Palace Hotel at Alexandria requests us to announce that it has decided to close the hotel from June 15 to October 1. [Advt.]
St Andrew's Schools.
To-morrow evening at 6 o'clock, a meeting will be held in the Scotch High School to to arrange a four months’ course in shorthand. Intending students are invited to attend.
Egypt and the Regie
It is rumoured that an Anglo-American Syndicate proposes to take up the Tobacco Monopoly in the Turkish Empire, after the expiration of the term of the present monopoly, i.e. six years hence.
Sudan Telephones

The Sudan Posts and Telegraphs Department has ordered, and is expecting shortly to receive, a large stock of telephone wire and other materials. Its stock is now so exhausted that no new telephones can he installed.
Slavo Traffic.

During the month of May last 17 slaves were liberated, there being 1 male and 3 female Soudanese at Assouan, 2 male and 5 female Soudanese and two Circassians at Cairo, also 3 males, Soudanese, and one Abyssinian at Alexandria.
The Legislative Counoil.

A the meeting of the Legislative Council held on Saturday, Article 5 of the law regard­ing the payment of taxes on State Domains was adopted. Certain other propositions which were brought forward were referred to the next session.
Egyptian Companies List.

The Secretary of the British Chamber of Commerce requests us to announce that, owing to a delay on the part of the printers, the new " List of Companies established in Egypt " will not be ready’ for publication until the 20th. inst., or possibly the 21st inst.
Bank of Athens.

The Bank of Athens inaugurated a new agency at Khartoum on Friday last. Mr. George Stamatapoulo is director, Mr. D. Zachiri, sub-director, and Mr. Const. Zafiro- poulo chief accountant. The inauguration of this new agency has been welcomed in the commercial and financial circles of the capital of the Sudan.
The Plague.

The last report to hand shows very little diminution in plague returns. Alexandria records one new case and a death out of hospital ; a recovery is reported at Beba; one fresh case at Beni Mazar ; 2 recoveries at Deirout; one fresh case and a death out of hospital at Esneh. The total number of cases under treatment are 35.
Public Health Department.

The Ottoman Sanitary Department has telegraphed to the Ministry-of the Interior to the effect that by the decision of the Supreme Council at Constantinople, arrivals from Alex­andria should be subjected to a medical visit and disinfection. It was further decided that bills of health would be annotated with the fact of the existence of cattle plague in the provinces of Sharkieh and Fayoum.
A Curious Accident.

As a train from the Alexandria Sporting Club was going to the city on Saturday even­ing a couple of carts tried to cross in front of it at Chatby. They both succeeded but one of them was stopped by a shawish on reaching the other side of the line, while the other got away. The usual alteration ensued between the carter and the policeman, the former having descended from his box. Meanwhile the cart began to slip backward and fell over the embankment, which was a drop of about four and a half metres. The accident created considerable excitement among the passengers on the train returning from the races. The other cart was afterwards caught by the police.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS
DEPUTATION TO SIR E GORST
div.p: The committee of the Alexandria Stock and Shareholders Association have formed a de­putation, who will be received by Sir Eldon Gorst at the summer quarters of the British Agency at Bulkeley at 4 o’clock this afternoon. The deputation will consist of Mr. Clement Snares, President of the Alexandria Bourse Committee, Mr. Alfred Campos, Vice-President, and Messrs. Carlo Salinas and Carlo Sofio. The object of the deputation is to set before the British Diplomatic Agent the views of the Committee on the existing financial crisis and to ask Sir Eldon Gorst to use his influence in extricating the money market front its present difficulties.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive is embarking on Saturday next on board the Mahroussa at Alexandria. His Highness will leave for Constantinople on the following day. Fakhry Pasha will accompany the Khedive.
On Thursday next at 9 a.m. the Khedive will visit the Mosque of Abou el-Abbas and attend the theological masque students course at the mosque

div.head: ALEXANDRIA JEWELLRY ROBBERY
ENGLISHMAN ARRESTED.
div.p: Yesterday an Englishman was arrested at Port Said on suspicion of being the man who recently took a room at the Carlton Hotel at Bulkeley and stole valuable jewellry belonging to Messrs. Magnin.of Cherif Pasha street Alex­andria The Alexandria City Police had from the outset strong s- spicions as to the identity of the theif. They obtained the original of the telegram despatched by the man to the Carlton Hotel. On comparing it with his handwriting, of which the police- had specimens, it was seen to tally exactly. As it was known that he had not left the country the ports of departure were watched with the result that he was captured at Port Said. The man is an English gentleman by birth and was once well known in Egypt. He was at one time in the service of the Egyptian Government. He has been handed over to the British Consular authorities at Alexandria.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB
div.p: The Alexandria Swimming Club has reason to congratulate itself upon the opening meet­ing of its fifth season, for it was more success­ful than any season’s inauguration that they have been able to register. Extra interest was added to the meeting by the arrangement of a water polo match against a team from H.M.S. “Diana.” Throughout the match play was very keep, but the ‘Diana” team was over­matched from the start, the Swimming Club being finally victorious by 8 goa’s to nil. The ‘Diana” team was without practice, and the Swimming Club team made an excellent combination, and it was largely due to their cleverness in passing that they were able to claim such a handsome victory. The team from the “Diana” were greatly pleased with the match, and another one has been arranged for next Saturday, when it is not at all im­possible that fortunes will be reversed. A team race of 420 yards, each member of the teams swimming 60 yards, will also be swum be­tween the “Diana” and the club, and judging from Saturday’s form the race should be a very very close and exciting one. In Saturday’s polo match Lloyd, Ecclestone, and Darton, playing forward, were a very useful com­bination, the former two players scoring two goals in the first half, and the last named one. In the second half Ecclestone scored another two goals, and Darton was also responsible for another. The referee of the match was Mr. H. S. Martin, the energetic honorary secretary of the Club. After the polo match and team race of next Saturday there will be a GO yards club handicap.

div.head: GUARENTEE OF PEACE
NEW TRIPLE ALLIANCE
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Monday.

I understand that the new agreement between England and France and Spain provides for the maintenance of the status quo of those parts of the Mediterranean and the Atlantic which affects the freedom of communications of the contracting Powers with their respective possessions. The agreement, which is consider­ed as a fresh guarantee of peace, has been communicated to the other Powers.
Saturday’s Cologne “Gazette” says that if three Powers guarantee the integrity of each other’s possessions, it would be long before the agreement could be put to a practical test.

div.head: DISSOLUTION OF DUMA
div.p: INCOMPATIBILITY OF GOVERNMENT.
Gazette's Special Service
London, Monday.

The “Times” is of the opinion that the true cause of the dissolution of the Duma is the incompatibility of Parliamentary Govern­ment with the principles of autocracy. The third Duma is likely to be even more extremist than the second

div.head: THE CROMER MEMORIAL
div.p: The following circular has been addressed to the British residents of Alexandria by Mr. Robert J. Moss:—
“You may have heard that the “Local Inter­national Council” lias postponed taking further action in this matter until after the summer, say next November.

“In the hope of keeping in touch with you, I venture to ask the favour of your opinion as to the form the testimonial should take, as it seems to me that it might be of some assistance to us all if the views of the British colony could be ascertained before the matter is again brought before the general public.

“May I therefore request you to let me have your reply in the enclosed envelope within the next few days ? I ask this in my capacity as chairman of the meeting, held, on the 2Gth April, at the British Club, Alexandria.

“I need scarcely say that your response will bee considered as an expression of opinion with­out prejudice and will in no way be looked upon as interfering with the work of any committee or Council which may be appointed here or elsewhere to discuss the proposal.”

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alex­andria, is leaving Alexandria on Thursday week, the 27th inst. by the Florio-Rubattino steamer for Europe. His Excellency will proceed -by Naples and Rome to the Alps.

Captain Dudley de Chair, R.N., who com­manded one of the cruiser escorts of the King and Queen of Denmark on their passage from Flushing, was in the beginning of his career about the time of the Egyptian war, and is one of the very few naval officers who have ever found themselves inside a Pasha’s harem. However, he was taken prisoner by Arabi Pasha’s people, and his sprightliness and tender years so commended him to his captors that he was relegated to the custody of Arabi’s family circle. There he so commended himself that, when the time came for him to go back to duty, his fair custodians were as loth to let him go as, doubtless, he was to leave them.

We regret to announce the death, which took place on Friday, the 7th inst. at 33, The Chase, Clapham Common, S.W., of Mary Elizabeth Mathew, wife of Sidney H. Wells, of the Ministry of Public Instruction and late Principal of the Battersen Polytechnic. The deceased was the eldest daughter of the late George Mathew, of Worsted Lodge, Cambridge, and was born on Dec. 12th, 1858 and married on Aug. 6th, 1890. The interment took place at Bramshott, Liphook, Hants, on Tuesday last.
Mrs. Nathan, wife of Mr. Alfred Nathan, of Cairo, gave birth to a son, at Victoria Hotel, Kensington, on the 4th inst.

Among the visitors staying at the Carlton Hotel, Ramleh are Mr. E. L. Edgar; Mine Macropolo ; Baron and Baroness von Pitner ; the Misses Pitner. Mr. C. Palmer, Mr. and Mrs. A. H. div.head: LOCUSTS IN THE SUDAN
div.p: Swat-ms of locusts appeared in Khartoum yesterday week. They did not stay long and were moving to the west.
Locusts in great number arrived at Abu Hamed on the 5th inst., moving in a northerly direction.
Scattered locusts have arrived at Darner. At present there are not enough to do damage. They are inclined to drift in a northerly direc tion on reaching the river.

div.head: ANGLOEGYPTIAN LAND ALLOTMENT COMPANY.
div.p: The Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Company has been making considerable progress on its Cyprus estates during this year. All through the spring the lands, which were purchased from the Cyprus Government last year, were being taken up. The crops were sown between October and February last, and are now being reaped. A number of steam ploughs have arrived lately at Famagusta for the Company’s agricultural operations. This year’s crops are excellent and threshing has lately begun. Each of the districts, Famagusta, Larnaca and Limassol, where the company’s lauds are situated, has a steam thresher. Since last year’s balance sheet was issued the Company has purchased land at Famagusta to the extent of a thousand feddans. It will be partly utilised for the cultivation of cereals and partly for market gardens. The cost averaged £3. 15s per feddan. At Famagusta nine new stores have been completed and let since the detailed statement of the Company’s Operations was published in our columns when the balance sheet appeared. The Fama- gqste branch of the Imperial Ottoman Bank has lately moved into the new building erected by the. Company and the Eastern Telegraph Company is in the course of this month moving into its new premises at Famagusta, which have been built by the Company. Besides these buildings a number of new shops and stores are being built. A steam dairy has been established by the Company at Famagusta and has been working during the last two months with very satisfactory results. Six branches of the Company’s Agricultural Bank are now at work throughout the island. At the beginning of June the amount out on loan was £40,000. Nearly all the loans are for periods of from 10 to 15 years. Borrowers pay at the rate of 9 percent per annum.

The centre of the Company’s operations in Cyprus is at Famagusta. The prosperity of this port is assured as it lias become the maritime terminus of the Cyprus Government Railway since the new harbour works have been completed. The customs and railway receipts are steadily increasing and capital is coming into the town. During the first three months of this year the returns of the port totalled more than the whole of the returns during last year. As the future success and prosperity of the new port is fully secured and will, in due course of time, be realized, the property, which the Company now owns there must rise con­siderably in value.

A large part of the land belonging to the Company in Egypt has been sold during the course of this year. The amount received in purchase money is £35,000. It was sold at about 25 per cent over the cost price.

In reference to the establishment of the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment in Cyprus it is worth noting that when this company' began its operations in the island some imaginative Cypriot Greeks declared that it was a Jewish concern and would aim at the introduction of Jews into Cyprus. There are very few Jews in the island and in the last census in 1901 they numbered only 118 persons, owning about 3,500 acres of land, out of a total population of 237,022. But the Greeks of Cyprus have a terrible fear of the Jews, dating from the time of Trajan, when the Jews of Cyprus and of the Eastern Mediterranean generally rose against the imperial Government, apparently with a view to the establishment of a separate Jewish state. They are said to have put to death 240,000 Gentiles in Cyprus, and in consequence it was enacted that no Jew might even set foot upon the island, and death there even awaited the shipwrecked Israelite. The dread caused by this revolt has endured for generations and when the rumour started that Sir William Willcocks’s company intended to advance Jewish interests in the island, the local Greek Press became very alarmed and columns of criticism ensued. The rumour has died a natural death.

div.head: NEW CANAL TUG
div.p: (From our own Correspondent).
Port Said, Sunday.

This morning a new tug boat, named the “Hercule” arrived for the Suez Canal Co. The “Hercule” is a sister tug to the “Titan,” which was built at South Shields some eight years ago, but is more powerful in fact the “Hercule”, is supposed to have greater towing power than any vessel of the kind afloat. She is a twin- screw vessel 150 feet long, her propelling machinery is of 3,000 indicated horse power, and consists of two sets of triple compound engines. She has a couple of powerful centri­fugal salvage pumps and a special steam fire pump, to say nothing of exceptionally strong deck machinery designed in connection with her towage work.

note.p: L.E. M.
„ Managing Directors’ Salaries
payable in advance with their
several agreements .... 2.283 111
„ Balance Carried to Balance

The following is the report of the directors which is to be submitted to the shareholders at the First Annual General Meeting to be held at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, at 5 5' oclock this afternoon:—

The directors present herewith to the share­holders their report and balance sheet for the period dating from the incorporation of the company to the 31st March 1907, duly certified by the auditors in accordance with the com­panies acts.

The company was registered on the 16th February and commenced business on the 5th April 1906, the accounts therefore cover a period of rather less than twelve months, and show a net trading profit of L.E. 12,149,330.

Considering the exceptional conditions exist­ing in the building trades in Egypt, and that a large proportion of the capital has only been available for about six months the directors are of opinion that this result is very satis factory.

The directors recommend the payment of a dividend of 7%, but in view of the important contracts which the company have at present on hand, consider it advisable to defer the payment of the same for the present.

The hoard were given an opportunity of securing the well known businesses of Messrs Grant, Bondi and Chinn, sanitary engineers and Messrs Mark G. Boyes and Co. engineers, upon very favourable terms, and as their acquisition would very materially strengthen the position of the Company, agreements were entered into for the purchase of both businesses and they accordingly were taken over by this company from the 1st January 1907.

In order to carry through these agreements the nominal capital of the company has been increased to £200,000 by the creation of 100,000 additional ordinary shares of £l each, according to the company’s articles of associa­tion.

The company have also acquired at a low price two feddans of land on the banks of the Nile at Rod el Farag, near the Embabeh Bridge, and are erecting thereon workshops stores and foundry, with up to date plant and fools. It is the intention of the directors to remove the various branch workshops to this centre.

It is anticipated that when these works are completed in the course of the next few months, they will be able to fulfil not only all our own requirements but those of other firms for all kinds of woodwork, castings, etc., and will enable the company to greatly extend its business.
During the year the company have been successful in obtaining a number of important contracts with the Egyptian Governments, the Army of Occupation, public companies and private individuals.
On account of ill health Mr. McClure has tendered his resignation which has been accepted.
Mr. David S. Bondi is joining the Board.
Mr. Gco. Nungovich Bey, retires by rotation, but being eligible offers himself for re-election
The Auditors, Messrs. Russell Kerr and Wyatt, retire under the Articles of Association but offer themselves for re-election.

div.head: AEGYPTIACA
div.p: A NEW WORK UPON ANCIENT EGYPTIAN RELIGION
By Joseph OFFORD.
(Continued from Saturday)
M. Naville evidently considers the tableaux, upon the tomb walls as merely indicative, or productive, of parallel environment in the next world for the defunct

It is worthy of note, however, that every scene of these panoramas may be connected also with the provision of a princely funeral feast. The culture of grain, plants, herbs and flowers, the harvest and granaries, the cattle rearing, fishing, and netting of birds, the weaving for funerary garments, papyrus growing and making for the rituals, seal and signet manufacture for the priests, beer brewing for beverages, tree cultivation to build the funeral boat, and make the sleigh, or chariot, for the sarcophogus, quarrying for the stelae, arid statuette making for the Ushabtis, and sculp­tor’s for the Ka statues, goldsmiths, and embroiders for funerary amulets and draperies. The preparing of animal skins for the boot-sails the writing of the “Book for the dead,” brick making for the tomb, dressing and cooking all the menu for the sepulchral banquet, will account for every action depicted in the Sakkara Mastabas.

Is it not possible that the whole “mise eu scene” has a double object—to describe with much exaggeration the funeral feast prelimina­ries and functions, here on earth: and to secure it repetition for the deceased “quand” “qu’il ait une bonne sepulture dans l’Occident” As M. Naville says the raison d’etre for the whole custom “must not be applicable” (solely) “to the tomb in which we find the stela; erected when it was completed, but to an ideal tomb in the west the duplicate of that an earth.”

If this is so,it appears to us that the Elysian field scenes are not those of a future “country seat” life of the dead Egyptian, but the pro­duction of the next world sepulchral service, and festival. The justified Egyptian is not a squire in a county home of the Am-Tuat but a fellow passenger with Ra and his crew of deities in the Sim god’s ship—when having been acquitted hit he hall of judgment, and his second funeral in hades fulfilled, he is free to “go in and out and came forth by day.” M. Naville devotes some space to the question as to whether human sacrifice was an Egyptian practice, and decides in the negative. As be says had it been enacted it is inexplicable that among the innomerable religious tableaux it should be unrepresented. He refers to the relief in a Theban tomb where two “Nubians” also styled Anon are apparently going to be executed, and concludes they were images of men, and the sacrifice was a theatrical one reminiscent of the execution of Anou prisoners of war in the early period campaign of Horus celebrated in the “Festival de frapper les Auou ” That human beings were occasionally imolated, as elsewhere, he does not deny. The evidence accumulated by M. Lefebvre in his “Bites Egyptians’* relating to edifices proves it, but these instances are exceptional and not part of funerary customs. The chapter upon rites and ceremonies, the divinity of the king, and the daily worship, has little that is new to readers of the works of Lefebvre and Moret. M. Naville says “Je croire que le culte des rois morts n’est qne la prolongation de celui qu’on leur rendait pendant leur vie. A mon sens les dieux n’ont pas ete d’abord des morts. Et ceci me conduit a une conclusion differente de celle de M. Moret Je croire au contraire qu'ils ont d’abord ete des vivants pour les- quels on a continue peut-etre en le mopifiaut ou en developpant ce qu’on faisait pour eux pendant leur vie.

This apparently means that the deities possessing temples and cults in Egypt were deified human beings ; such as Imlotep probab­ly was, we suppose the tribal chiefs, whose animal emblem became theirs when deified. To become a god one must have first been a king, or chief, whilst later to be borne a Pharaoh was to involve and insure being acclaimed a god.

M. Naville says that the amulet, or figure known as the dad or tah, a sort of double column supporting 4 cross bars is representa­tive of the spinal column with the projecting ribs of the vertebrate man, and says the texts leaves us in no doubt as to this, but he does not quote any one of them.

This symbol has mostly been considered to exemplify stability or firmness, and to have been an hieratic representation of the 4 comer world pillars which support (according to Egyptian theories) the firmament shown in perspective.
We think there is a good deal to be said for this view of the case and consider the matter at present as undecided.

One of the lectures discussed the Doctrine of Heliopolis and the Egyptian Enneads. The role of Ammon at Thebes, and the religious reforms of Amenophis IV. These last .it is now- evident were not induced by any foreign in­fluence. It was a selection of a particular form of the deity to have offered to him solely, a type of worship already familiar probably in many temples. It was not a reform of doctrine but intended to disqualify the varieties of theology and doctrine which separated the teaching of the many sacerdotal colleges and merge into one form of worship the religious cults of the whole of Egypt

Naturally the author quotes more than usual from texts at Der-elBahari also from other literature first edited by himself such as “The Myth of the Destruction of Mankind by the Gods” but all the more important publications of inscriptions and papyri are drawn upon and a short, but select, bibliography is appended to each chapter.

div.head: SOCIETE DES CIMENTS D’EGYPTE
div.p: Les bénéfices industriels de l’année 1906 ont atteint L.K 5016; mais, après déduction des frais d’administration, intérêts, amortissements et dépenses extraordinaires, c’est par un déficit de LE. 1060 que se solde l’exercice. En ajoutant à ce chiffre le déficit à fin 1905, on arrive au total global de L.E. 14.207,qui représente le solde débiteur à fin 1906. La décision prise par l’Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire, teuue à Bruxelles, le 20 Avril dernier, de réduire le capital de moitié, permettra de rayer complètement ce passif du bilan futur et d a- mortir, en outre, d’une seule fois, les primes sur les émissions d’obligations ainsi que les frais d’inscription hypothécaire, tout en con stituant à la Société une réserve de 17 % environ.

La fabrication a produit en 1906 20.307 tonnes de ciment, dont il a été vendu 19016 tonnes. Il reste un stock total de 3662 tonnes. En 1905 les ventes n’avaient été que de 6531 tonnes. Pour les 5 premiers mois de 1907 elles atteignent 10548 contre 6435 en 1906. Le pied de production actuel, qui est de 30000 tonnes, va être porté à 36000, des contrats assurant l’écoulement d’une telle quantité pour 1908- 1910 étant déjà passés avec divers clients.
Comparé avec celui de 1905, le bilan de 1906 montre une notable nmélioiation, puisque la perte a été réduite à L. E. 1060, tandis qu'en 1905 elle avait été de 6825.

L’émission nouvelle des 15,000 actions privilégiées de 50 francs, en vue de reconstituer le capital social diminué de moitié aura lieu en Novembre prochain. Cette émission, déduction faite des frais d’émission, produira une somme de 700000 fr., qui permettra de rembourser en intérêts et capital les 318000 fr. de la Caisse des Propriétaires, ainsi que les 200000 fr. avancés par la Banque d’Athènes. Il restera 180000 fr. pour acquérir le matériel nécessaire et agrandir les installations en vue de mettre l’usine sur un pied de production de 36.000 tonnes.

div.head: 34 YEARS OF RHEUMATISM
div.p: Patient laid up in Bed for 10 Months at a time, Disabled and Helpless.
4, York street,
Bilston, Staffs., England

Gentlemen : — I will always do what I can towards making your Doan's Backache Kidney Pills better known, because they have proved such a blessing to me, and I believe in them. I have been a martyr to rheumatism ever since I was 20 years of age, and now I am 54 When quite a young man I had to walk with crutches or sticks. This went on for over tliree years, and since that time I have never l>een properly free from the rheumatism, but never so free as I am at the present time, since using Doan’s Pills.

During those 34 years I had several severe attacks of this terrible rheumatism. The one in October of 1897, when I was living in Wed- nesbury, was, I think, the severest attack I ever had ; it kept me in my bed for 10 months, -and I became as helpless as a new born babe. 1 was attended by one of the best doctors, but he seemed unable to do me much good, although he told me more than once that if I had been a millionaire he could not have tried harder—and I believe him.

In March of 1899 I was kept from business for 17 months again with rheumatisn and kidney trouble. There were severe pains in my back and sides (esjiecially the left side) ; my appetite became poor, and I didn’t relish the food I was able to eat. There was a nasty taste in my mouth, no matter what 1 ate or drank, and I couldn’t keep my food down. Even a pipe of tobacco seemed to go against me, and I became despondent and miserable, feeling that life was not worth living.

But there was worse to follow : not long after, I began to be troubled with the "kidney secretions, the pain in passing being almost unbearable at times. There was also a sediment from the urine. These distressing complaints kept getting worse and worse as months went by, until one day I couldn’t pass the urine at all ; I was in such a terrible condition at the time that I thought my race was nearly run.

It was then that I heard about Doan’s Backache Kidney Pills, and they were spoken so highly of that I determined to try them. After I had taken a few boxes I felt easier, and now that I have taken ten boxes I feel quite free from any sign of rheumatism or kidney trouble. I am a new man to what I was, thanks to your Doan’s Backache Kidney Pills. They are indeed worth their weight in gold.
Hoping you will excuse this long letter, and again thanking you for my new health and strength, I remain,
Yours very gratefully,
(Signed) Charles Osborne.

Doan’s Backache Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 13 per box, or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes ; or they may be had direct from the general agent for Egypt,— Max Fischer, Hotel du Nil Street, Mousky, Cairo.

div.head: LIBERA^ GOVERNMENT’S POLICY.
div.p: London, June 15.

The Government’s resolution dealing with the House of Lords says, that in order to give effect to the will of the people, expressed by the elected representatives, it is necessary that t he power of the Lords to alter or reject a Bill passed by the House of Commons should be so restricted as to secure that within the limits of a single Parliament'the final decision of the House of Commons shall prevail. (R.)
London, June 15.

The Liberal press cordially approves of the Government resolution with reference to the Lords, pointing ont that while it declares the ministerial policy it postpones rightly, legislative action thereupon until the eve of dissolution

The Unionist papers are disposed to ridicule the resolution which has been produced, they say, after so much talk. They emphasize the fact that a law is required before it can take effect, and recognise at the same time that a grave constitutional reform is enunciated in the resolution. (Reuter)

div.head: SITUATION IN RUSSIA.
div.p: THE DUMA DISSOLVED.
St. Petersburg, June 15.

A crisis has occurred in the Dunm. M. Stolypin demanded the exclusion of 55 members wilom, he alleged, were concerned in a com-jpiracy to establish a Republic; He also ^Cîmanded the arrest of 16 of them. The Duma, despite the Government’s opposition, referred the matter to a committee. The dissolution of the Duma is regarded as probable.
(Reuter)
St. Petersburg, June 15.
Cossacks are occupying all stations in the city.
The Duma has adjourned until Monday.
(Reuter)
St. Petersburg, June 16.
An Imperial Ukase has been issued this morning dissolving the Duma and fixing the dute of the new elections at 1st September’ The new Duma will open on the 1st November.
(Reuter)
St. Petersburg, June 16.
An ukase has been issued dissolving the Duma and fixing the elections for the 14th of September and the convocation of the new assembly for November 14. (Havas)
St. Petersburg, June 16.

The Tsar has issued a manifesto declaring tliat the new Duma must be Russian in spirit; other nationalities in the Empire will be represented but not in sufficient number to enable them to decide purely Russian questions. Where the people had not attained sufficient civic development the elections would be temporarily suspended.

Simultaneously a new electoral law proclaimed which reduces the membership of the Duma from 524 to 442. In Poland, Siberia, and the Caucasus the elections will be held under special regulations. Poland loses 26 deputies.

The manifesto expresses disappointment at the conduct of many of the members of the Duma. It refers to the conspiracy of 15th November and the failure of the Duma to suspend the accused members, for which reason it had been dissolved.

The dissolution was received quietly here. The city is full of troops, quartered in the principal thoroughfares. Extraordinary measures have been taken to ensure order. Rioting is practically impossible. The Prefect has prohibited hostile press comments. Numerous arrests have been made already, including 9 of the accused members of the Duma. (Reuter)

div.head: MEDITERRANEAN
div.p: ATLANTIC.
ENGLAND, FRANCE, AND SPAIN.
London, June 15.

Great Britain and Spain, and France and Spain have concluded treaties guaranteeing their respective positions in the Mediterranean and Atlantic. Exchange notes embodying these have been communicated to all the Powers, including Germany.

div.head: FRENCH WARSHIPS ON FIRE
div.p: CASES OF INCENDAIRISM
Paris, June 6
Incendiary fires have occurred during the past few days on two French warships lying in Toulon.
Cases of insubordination in the army continue
PEACE CONFRENCE OPENS
THE HAGUE, JUNE 15

The Peace Conference have opened. M. Nelidoff has been elcted President of the Conference. He said that their task was to seek a means of amicably settling differences between States and thus arresting the cause of irritation, and secondly to migrate the effects of war, alike for combattants and those indirectly affected. (Reuter)
THE HAGUE, JUNE 16

The proceedings at the Conerence yesterday were formal, only lasting 20 minutes. As a spectaclethe 239 envoys, representing 47 power, were not particulary imposing owing to the absence of uniforms by request of the Dutch Government, through it was immensly signigicant from the fact that every civilized country on the globe is represented for the first time. (Reuter)
THE TRANSVAAL.
CHINESE REPATRIATION.
London, June 15.

General Botha’s announcement, implying the repatriation of 16,000 Chinese .before the end of the year and a total clearance by 1909, has caused consternation in the mining industry which disputes his assertion that there is a sufficient supply of Kaffiirs available.
The Ministerial papers highly eommend his declaration.. The Unionists affirm unhesitatingly that his policy has been influenced by the guaranteed loan. (Reuter)
TROUBLE IN PERSIA.
Tiflis, June 16.
The Persian Consul and his secretary have been attacked by a revolutionary band. The secretary was killed but the Consul escaped unhurt. His assailant has been arrested. (R.)
AUSTRIAN PARLIAMENT.
Vienna, June 16.
The Emperor has appointed Prince de Win- dischgraetz president of the House of Lords.
( Havas')
WINE-GROWERS’ TROUBLE-
Narbonne, June 16.
The Government intends to arrest the principal agitators in the wine-growers’ trouble.
( Havas)
THE GRAND PRIX.
Paris, June 16.
Sans Souci II. has won the Grand Prix. (U.)
Paris, June 16.
Grand Prix de Paris. 1. Sans Souci II ; 2. Mordant;3. Ping-Pong. (Reuter)
HOME CRICKET.
London, June 15.
Notts beats Sussex by 9 wickets. Worcestershire beat Gloucestershire by 8 wickets.
The match between Middlesex and Yorkshire has been abandoned.(Reuter)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
div.p: AMATEUR RACE MEETING.

Rather damp and uncomfortable weather prevailed, and the meeting seemed to lack the brilliancy and animation of a professional meeting, although on the whole sport was good and no fault conld be found with the quality and quantity of the horses competing Prom the attendance when the first race was rung up it almost looked as if the meeting would be a disappointment but things livened up later on, and the afternoon’s sport was enjoyed by those who were present. Considerable interest was centred upon the match between Saiadll and Moofid. At their last meetingSaiad II Was third with Moofid unplaced the latter conceding 10 lb. With now only 7 lb. difference in the weights Saiad II admirably ridden by Whiteside confirmed this running by winning fairly easily. There was very little to choose between them until entering the straight when Thompson had to wake Moofid up with the whip, but Whiteside riding ooolly had him beaten and passed the post a couple of lengths to the good.
An excellent selection of music was played during the afternoon by the band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers conducted by Sand- master A. Fawcett v

div.head: A WARNING IN SEASON.
div.p: HOW TO CURE LASSITUDE-

Our duty is to forewarn you against anemia and lassitude, which are prevalent in times of great heat. The feebleness gains on you slowly, and you do not consequently take sufficient notice of it. This is exactly where you do wrong ; there is always a certain amount of danger in letting the system grow feeble, however slightly. If the heat lias at all upset you, we would strongly advise you to take Dr. Williams’ Pink Pills. They will not fail to arrest, by giving an increased quantity of blood and new strength, your weakness. In submitting to you the statement of M. M. Marioni Ludovico writes : About three years ago I began to be ansemic. I was pale and I didn’t feel fit for anything. I developed these various ailments as the result of bronchitis. div.p: Company, Limited.
ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING
TO BE HELD AT
THE NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPr,
on Saturday, June 22nd, 1907,
At 4 o’clock, p.m.

MOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the ANNUAL ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the Company will be held at the National Bank qf Egypt,on Saturday, 22nd June, 1907. at 4 o’clock p.m. precisely, for the purpose of receiving the Directors’ Report and Balance Sheet for the year ended 31st March, 1907, and fixing the Dividend, electing Directors in the place of those retiring, appointing Auditors for the ensuing year and fixing their remuneration, an«l transacting the Ordinary General Business of the Company.
Dated this 13th day of June 1907.
By or«ler of the Board,
R.Q. HENRIQUES,
General Manager. 2, Shareh Bank el Watani, Cairo.

N.B.—Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to Bearer, and whose names are not on the Share Registers of the Company, are reminded that if they wish to attend this General Meeting of the Company, they must first tleposit their Bearer Warrants together with a statement in writing of their names and addresses, at any of the following Banks two clear days before the date of the Meeting, viz. : not later than the 20th June, 1907 : The National Bank of Egypt ; The Bank of Egypt ; The Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd. ; Credit Lyonnais, or Imperial Ottoman Bank. The Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held. Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, which must be produced by the Holders attending the Meeting. 30488-4*-2

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: There was stolen yesterday by an employée in the office of Messrs. Moursi Brothers well known cotton merchants of this city the sum of £600 sterling in National Bank Notes, amongst them being five notes of L.E. 100 each bearing the following numbers, 18,136, 28,882, 30,259, 30,260, and 30,740. It is requested that in case any of these notes are presented, information will be given immediately to the Alexandria City Police, who are actively engaged on the case. The notes have been stopped at the Bank. 30491-10-2

div.head: The Egyptian Hotels Limited.
div.p: NOTICE is hereby given that the Tenth Annual General Meeting of The Egyptian Hotels Limited will be held at the Registered Offices of the Company, No. 11 Ironmonger Lane, London, E.C., on Monday the first day of July 1907 at 4 p.m. Any holder of Share Warranta to Bearer desirous of attending and voting thereat must, seven days before the date of the said Meeting, deposit the said Share Warrants at one of the undermentioned Banks, and shall receive a Certificate entitling him to attend and vote at the aforesaid General Meeting :
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd., London, Paris, Cairo, and Alexandria.
The Banque Commerciale de Bâle, Basle(Switz- erland).
The National Bank of Egypt, Cairo.
The Comptoir National d’Escompte «le Paris, Cairo.
The Société Générale Egyptienne, Cairo.
W. B. Peat & Co., Secretaries.

Avis est donné par la présente qu’une Deuxième Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire de la Compagnie aura lieu au Bureau de la Compagnie il Alexandrie le Jeudi le 4 Juillet 1907 à 4 h. p.m. pour confirmer les résolutions approuvées à l’Assemblée Générale Extraor. dinaire le 11 Juin 1907.
1 L’augmentation du Capital de la Compagnie par la création de 20,000 nouvelles actions de £5 nominales chacune, exclnsiveinentoffertes aux Actionnaires.
2. De donner pouvoirs au Conseil «l’Administration d’émettre ces actions en totalité ou en partie, au moment et au prix qu’il jugera opportun dans l’intérêt de la Compagnie.

Pour assister on se faire représenter à cette Assemblée, MM. les propriétaires d’actions an porteur sont informés que, conformément aux Statuts, leurs titres doivent être tléposés A FAnglo-Egyptian Bank, Ltd. à Alexandrie, au moins trois jours francs, avant l’Assemblée ou chez Messrs. Barclay and Company Ltd. 1, Pall Mall East, London. S.W., à Londres 14 jours francs, avant l’Assemblée.
Par ordre du Conseil d’Administration,
H.R.C. BLAGDEN Directeur.

div.head: Industrial, Building and Commercial Company of Egypt Limited.
div.p: AVIS

Les Titres definitifs au porteur des actions ordinaires de la susdite Societe seront a la disposition des interesses A PARTIR DU 17 COURANT, a la cassa di sconto e di Risparmio a Alexandrie et an Caire, qui est chargee de les livrer contre remise de la lettre de reparition (allotment letter) entierement liberee et du recu de depot delivre a la souscription.
A pertir de la date sunsindiquee tout actionnaire en retard de paiement du derniervestment de .10 par action, sera passible d'un interet de 9% l'an.
